results.title: Rwanda
results.creator_credit: Joanne Harding, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Joanne Harding was sent to Rwanda as part of the Australian Defence Force medical Support Force. She focuses on the part of her experience that affected her the most, the eyes of the children. She describes their eyes as pools of nothingness as they begin to accept war as part of their everyday life. In turn, Joanne begins to question the effectiveness of her role and that of the United Nations in bringing peace to this wartorn country.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joanne Harding, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

She describes their eyes as pools of nothingness as they begin to accept war as part of their everyday life. In turn, Joanne begins to question the effectiveness of her role and that of the United Nations in bringing peace to this wartorn country.

results.title: An Interview with Peter Isaacson : pathfinder
results.creator_credit: Peter Isaacson and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Peter Isaacson tells his story of joining the Air Force in World War II and becoming part of the legendary Pathfinders. Peter also became famous for flying under the Sydney Harbour Bridge towards the end of World War II.

results.title: Monkey off my back
results.creator_credit: Ned Jeanes, Jack Gerdsen and ACMI
results.brief_description: Jack Gerdsen recounts his emotional return to the battleground in Korea 44 years later. He took with him soil from his backyard to honour and comfort his mates who fell there.

results.title: Hello Universe
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Most scientists are convinced that extra-terrestrial life does exist, estimating that the galaxy is swarming with life. But the hard evidence is disappointingly scarce and as the search program gathers pace a different viewpoint is emerging - that after all the human race is alone in the universe. This program explores the probabilities of galactic neighbours.
results.description:

results.title: An Interview with Pat Vines
results.creator_credit: Pat Vines and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Pat Vines joined the Australian Navy as a nurse during World War II. She moved up the ranks and eventually became a Commander. Pat tells her story through her memories of wartime and what it was like to work in the Navy.
results.description: Pat Vines joined the Australian Navy as a nurse during World War II. She moved up the ranks and eventually became a Commander. Pat tells her story through her memories of wartime and what it was like to work in the Navy.
description_for_label: Pat Vines joined the Australian Navy as a nurse during World War II. She moved up the ranks and eventually became a Commander. Pat tells her story through her memories of wartime and what it was like to work in the Navy.

results.title: How do you read?
results.creator_credit: Harris Watts, Stephen Rose and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Being unable to read is a personal disaster. Learning to read at an early age is very important. This film demonstrates various modern techniques and devices used to increase reading speed, and it shows that the speed of reading and the rate of comprehension are related to the material being studied.

results.title: An Interview with Warwick N. Johanson
results.brief_description: After joining the Navy when he turned 17, one of the first lessons Warwick Johanson learnt was that if anything moved, you saluted it, if it stood still, you polished it. His home for over four years was aboard the flagship, the HMAS Australia, often a target for the formidable Japanese Kamakaze. Warwick also reflects on World War II and what it was like in Australia, when the country was actually in peril, almost unimaginable in this day and age.
results.description: After joining the Navy when he turned 17, one of the first lessons Warwick Johanson learnt was that if anything moved, you saluted it, if it stood still, you polished it. Warwick also reflects on World War II and what it was like in Australia, when the country was actually in peril, almost unimaginable in this day and age.

results.title: Ghost of the Amoco Cadiz
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
In 40 years three major maritime casualties have changed the way ships are worked. The ghost of the biggest accident, the Amoco Cadiz, haunts the shipping industry, and a great deal of research work has been stimulated by the events of that fateful day.

results.title: An Interview with Pat Vines: The Shrine of Remembrance
results.creator_credit: Pat Vines and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: After Pat Vines returns from the war as a Commander of the Australian Navy, one of her senior navy officers recommends her to the Shrine of Remembrance Trustees, which she joins. She tells of her time as a Trustee for the Shrine.
results.title_for_label: An Interview with Pat Vines: The Shrine of Remembrance

results.title: Uranium goes critical
results.creator_credit: Richard Reisz and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”
Discusses the role of uranium in the world’s energy situation. Maintains that at the present rate of use, uranium fuel could be used up in 20 to 30 years. Deals with the safety aspects of using uranium as a source of energy and asks if we should be looking at alternative technologies instead.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”
Discusses the role of uranium in the world’s energy situation. Maintains that at the present rate of use, uranium fuel could be used up in 20 to 30 years. Deals with the safety aspects of using uranium as a source of energy and asks if we should be looking at alternative technologies instead.
